The first statement is a conditional statement: "If Tom watched football, then Jen watched basketball." In logical terms, this can be represented as "If P, then Q," where P is "Tom watched football" and Q is "Jen watched basketball."

The second statement is "Tom did not watch football," which is the negation of P, or "not P."

In logic, from "If P, then Q" and "not P," we cannot directly infer "not Q." This is a common logical fallacy known as "denying the antecedent." The truth of Q is not dependent solely on P being true; Q could still be true even if P is false. Therefore, from the given statements, we cannot conclude that Jen did not watch basketball.
